FROSH-SOPHOMORE
GAME CALLED OFF
The freshman - sophomore
game did not take place Saturday due to the fact that arrangements could not be made
for the occasion. Both the
sophomore and freshman rooters who went to the field Saturday were disappointed as interest was keen for the game.
This is the second time the
game has been called off and it
looks as if the old tradition of
an annual freshman - sophomore tilt is to be broken this
season for the first time in
many years. Arrangements
have not been made for playing the game at any time in the
future.

This, it was vouchsafed, has been
going on for the best part of 50
years and was largely responsible

The League for Independent
Political Action, it was revealed, is
concerned in equal amount with
both organization and the institution
of a new party. It hopes to gather
together the weakling advocates of
the cause and after firmly combining
them, to establish a single platform.
Interest Displayed

"I am confident," asserted Williams, "that once the merit of our
party is recognized, the progressives
of the other political units will desert to join the union alignment.
Trade groups and labor groups have
already begun to show a profound
interest in our work."
The position of the farmer, it

speaker, had it been passed, would

Three Men Lost

Only three men will be lost to the
team this year, but these men's loss
will be felt keenly.
Scheibe', who won consistently
last season in the long and middle
distance events, will be unable to
participate in the meets due to the
fact that he has been with the team
for four years and is now ineligible.
Debuskey, known to the campus
as a basketball player, but who also
got his varsity letter in track will
not be back. His javilin and discuss
throwing for the last several years
has always been of the best.
Morrison, also, will not be back.
He won his letter last year in the
dashes and was expected to beat a
few records this year, but he did not
return to college.
Of the other men who wear the
varsity "H" for track, there are
eleven who will compete again this
season. Several men who won only
the union letter, "AHA" last year
will be back and are expected to
help out the team considerably.
Frosh Material Unknown

members of this year's freshman
class. There is one fellow who
came to Hopkins from Friends
School who is expected to run the
dashes and is also loked to to win in
the broad jump events. Several men

FENCING CLUB TO
BE ORGANIZED HERE
In order to organize a fencing club at the University, E.
J. Biggs announces that a
meeting of all interested will
be held this week.
The project has been approved by Major McKinney,
P. M. S. and T., Coach Van
Orman and Mr. Iddins, as
well as the A. A. Board. The
planned organization will not
receive financial assistance
from the A. A. Board, according to Biggs. The club will
be organized with the intention of forming a team. No
equipment will be required at
the meeting, which is to be
held Thursday, December 12,
at 12.20 P. M. in the south
loft of Gilman Hall.

DR. BLOODGOOD IS
HONORED FOR WORK
Gold Medal Awarded WellKnown Surgeon
As a reward to his pursuit of
study in X-Ray work, Dr. Joseph
Colt Bloodgood, director of the
Garvan Experimental Laboratory of
the University and clinical professor of surgery, received an award
from the Radiological Society of
North America last week. The
award was in the form of a medal.
The recipient was not present at
the occasion of the award, a severe
cold being the cause of his absence.
The society formally recognized Dr.
Moodgood's activities in the field
of ray treatment, at its annual convention held this year in Toronto,
Canada. The convention spread
over a period of five days and was
attended by leading physicians and
surgeons from every part of the
United States and Canada.
Twenty other persons besides Dr.
Bloodgood have been similarly honored by receiving the medal. Early
in the year, Dr. Russel T. Haden,
Kansas City, Missouri, was recognized. Dr. Blodgood and Dr. Haden
are the only recipients this year.
Two women are among the twenty.
Mme. Curie, Paris, and Dr. Slye,
Chicago, holding this signal honor.

EDITORIALS

EDGEWORTH

T

It is always more or less difficult to draw up any list of characteristics
which will fit an ideal type. The so-called "characters" which originated
with the Greek philosopher Theophrastus and were later adopted by
Overbury, Earle, and Hall in English literature are more caricatures
than anything else. We do not think there is any definite set of traits
which can be ascribed to the ideal teacher. His type is varied. Some
are successful because they are speakers of ability who hold the attention of their classes; others use wit to gain student interest, some who
are students of their subject succeed because of the lucid manner in
which they "put across" their explanations, and still others are so well
regarded by their students on grounds of personality alone that the
actual work of the course becomes a pleasure.
No teacher who actually aspires to be more than a mere pedagogue
can put himself above the criticism of his students. Too frequently,
young and self-opinionated instructors are inclined to resent criticism
and older men become too set in their opinions. Only the teacher
who wins the admiration of his pupils can hope to make a success of
his profession.
P. W. S.

Debating Council
Sponsors Long Trip
Arrangements will soon be completed for the longest debating trip
ever undertaken by the Johns Hopkins Debating Council. It is estimated that 1500 miles will be
covered in five days, with debates
scheduled for each day. Syracuse
University has promised the Debating Council a capacity audience,
and a microphone, so that the debate may be broadcasted. The
subject for this debate will be "Resolved: That the generation and
transmission of hydro-electric power
should be undertaken by the government," with Hopkins upholding
the negative side. Colgate and Boston College plan to welcome the Jay
team with appropriate generosity,
and will insure a goodly audience
for the forensic discussions. At
these two schools the representatives
of Hopkins intelligensia will uphold the affirmative side of the question "Resolved: That a high protective tariff is detrimental to world
peace." Plans for debates with
Villanova and Temple are still in
progress.

DR. BLOODGOOD IS
HONORED FOR WORK
Gold Medal Awarded WellKnown Surgeon
As a reward to his pursuit of
study in X-Ray work, Dr. Joseph
Colt Bloodgood, director of the
Garvan Experimental Laboratory of
the University and clinical professor of surgery, received an award
from the Radiological Society of
North America last week. The
award was in the form of a medal.
The recipient was not present at
the occasion of the award, a severe
cold being the cause of his absence.
The society formally recognized Dr.
Moodgood's activities in the field
of ray treatment, at its annual convention held this year in Toronto,
Canada. The convention spread
over a period of five days and was
attended by leading physicians and
surgeons from every part of the
United States and Canada.
Twenty other persons besides Dr.
Bloodgood have been similarly honored by receiving the medal. Early
in the year, Dr. Russel T. Haden,
Kansas City, Missouri, was recognized. Dr. Blodgood and Dr. Haden
are the only recipients this year.
Two women are among the twenty.

EDITORIALS

EDGEWORTH

T

It is always more or less difficult to draw up any list of characteristics
which will fit an ideal type. The so-called "characters" which originated
with the Greek philosopher Theophrastus and were later adopted by
Overbury, Earle, and Hall in English literature are more caricatures
than anything else. We do not think there is any definite set of traits
which can be ascribed to the ideal teacher. His type is varied. Some
are successful because they are speakers of ability who hold the attention of their classes; others use wit to gain student interest, some who
are students of their subject succeed because of the lucid manner in
which they "put across" their explanations, and still others are so well
regarded by their students on grounds of personality alone that the
actual work of the course becomes a pleasure.
No teacher who actually aspires to be more than a mere pedagogue
can put himself above the criticism of his students. Too frequently,
young and self-opinionated instructors are inclined to resent criticism
and older men become too set in their opinions. Only the teacher
who wins the admiration of his pupils can hope to make a success of
his profession.
P. W. S.

GRAD STUDENT TENPINNERS TO
BEGIN ACTIVITIES NEXT WEEK
Again this year graduate students
of the various departments will loft
balls and send pins flying through
windows in their annual bowling
contest. An anonymous donor of
the Economics Department has
offered a cup to be presented to the
winning team.
The contest will be held during
the winter months. Only graduate
students will be eligible. Since
there are an even dozen graduate
departments it is expected that competition will be fierce and prolonged.
Last year the Political Science
and History Departments had affairs all their own way with the
Economics Department offering
competition. The "Historians" were
the victors. It is expected that the
"Geologists" will be grave contenders this year, due to the fact that
they are in good condition through
volley ball playing. On the other
hand, the "Historians" have lost
several of their star pin decapitators
by virtue of the awarding of Ph.
D's.

of the season in which summary it

of its 1929 season. The only loss

Average Scores Given
Coach Hambleton Gives Brief
Survey of Past Season

HOCHSCHILD,KOHN & CO.

3

The average scores of the individual runners was given by Coach
Hambleton. Herman Scheibel, who
ran his last harrier races this season, took first place in every meet
of the season, giving him an average
score of one point a meet for the
season.
Bob Kelly, who ran second to
Scheibel in all but one race, the
Maryland meet, from which he was
forced to drop because of an injury, had an average of two and a
half points a meet for the year.
After Kelly, Emerson placed, having made an average of four points
in the races. Waters averaged seven
points a race. Reeder and Miller
made an average of seven and a hafl
points for each five-mile run.
Packard, the only freshman to run
this year averaged seven and threequarter points.
All the men just mentioned received the "cHc," the cross-country
letters awarded by the Athletic Association.

Next year, with Emerson as captain, Hanlbleton, who will again
coach the Hill-and-Dalers, is looking forward to another good season.
Although Scheibel, Kelly, Waters
and Miller will not be with the team,
Packard will be back, as will be
Millstone, Sugarman and Goodman,
next year sophomores. This group
will be able to carry on the good
showing only if the other runners
in the University offer their support
and come out for practices.

Onorato May Be Back

Onorato, who should have been
captain had he been in college this
year, may be back as a medical student, if he is with the team it is
expected that he and Emerson will
fill the gaps left by Kelly and Scheibel.
When interviewed, Coach Hambleton said: "I am sorry to see such
a good team broken up by the loss
of the four men who will be ineligible next year. I look forward to
a very successful season next year,
but see a great need for new material."

Debating Council
Sponsors Long Trip
Arrangements will soon be completed for the longest debating trip
ever undertaken by the Johns Hopkins Debating Council. It is estimated that 1500 miles will be
covered in five days, with debates
scheduled for each day. Syracuse
University has promised the Debating Council a capacity audience,
and a microphone, so that the debate may be broadcasted. The
subject for this debate will be "Resolved: That the generation and
transmission of hydro-electric power
should be undertaken by the government," with Hopkins upholding
the negative side. Colgate and Boston College plan to welcome the Jay
team with appropriate generosity,
and will insure a goodly audience
for the forensic discussions. At
these two schools the representatives
of Hopkins intelligensia will uphold the affirmative side of the question "Resolved: That a high protective tariff is detrimental to world
peace." Plans for debates with
Villanova and Temple are still in
progress.

The Girl Number of the Black
and Blue Jay will make its appearance on December 20 instead of the

Jay, will have her portrait drawn
